instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message:
Board had some water damage near <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U8110</CHIP>, UB700
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 0V

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> 
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR_VIN</SIGNAL> 12.6V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_COREVR_VCC</SIGNAL> 5.1V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R</SIGNAL> 1.8V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message:
You can't expect USB activity without CPU core voltage.
Do you get voltage at L7702 and L8100/02?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message:
I could not think of a better name for the post, of course no CPU vcore voltage no USB activity.

L7702 0V
L8100 0.27V
L8102 0.63V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message:
Do you really get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> without correct voltage at L8100/02?
Please check on the output pin of the coils; where the filter cap is placed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message: Yes  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present at 1.8V and both coils were measured at both ends, I just realized that PCH is heating up a little, mac sits at 20V 0.181A after a few seconds of connecting power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message: You shouldn't get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> without L8100/02 voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message:
Are we talking about the same same board?
I do have  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and  L8100/02 voltages are too low, both those coils dont have caps at either end, both have a resitor <RESISTOR>R8118</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8102</RESISTOR> afther the coil, then after the resistor there are caps, I measured both ends a few times and get the same result.

Any other advice?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message:
I didn't consider the Isense resistors, as they are 2-3 miliohm only.

Check <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>/10 power good signals; pins 20 & 9 respectivelly.
You should get 0V, as both coils are out of +/-20% of expected voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message:
Seems to have problems with <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>/10.
Post more voltages.
<CHIP>U8100</CHIP>, pins 12, 6, 15, 16, 17.
<CHIP>U8110</CHIP>, pins 13, 14, 3, 12.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB Activity
threads.message: Upon further inspection I realized <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S_CPU</SIGNAL> was only present in some part of the board, after making a jumper wire get connected to <RESISTOR>R8154</RESISTOR> and now board boots up, your suggestions led me here, thanks a lot!
